block.para: Recall: A sequence (x_n) in \RNr converges to a number c if, for every \varepsilon > 0 there exists n_0\in \NNr such that

Intuitively speaking, the number x_n get ever closer to or equal to c as n tends to infinity. What we need to understand here is how this definition expresses this intuitively described behavior of the sequence.

li.para: Interpret the positive number \varepsilon as a ‘deviation tolerance’
Given n_0\in \NNr, interpret the subsequence (x_n), n\geq n_0 as a tail end of the original sequence.
Then the definition of convergence of (x_n) to c asserts: Given any positive deviation tolerance, there exists a tail end of the sequence which stays within the prescribed deviation tolerance of c.

block.para: It is important here that \varepsilon is allowed to range over all positive numbers. For each choice of \varepsilon some tail end of the sequence must exist which stays within the \varepsilon-prescribed deviation tolerance of c.
Let us address some possible questions about the definition of convergence:

li.para: We are not required to find a ‘longest possible’ tail end which stays within the \varepsilon-prescribed deviation tolerance.

We do not need to find a tail end which works simultaneously for all \varepsilon > 0. To the contrary, the smaller we choose \varepsilon, the larger we will in general have to choose the number which marks the beginning of the tail end of sequence elements which stays within the \varepsilon-prescribed deviation tolerance.

Read this as: ‘For all epsilon greater than 0, there exists n-zero in N such that for all n greater than or equal to n-zero the absolute value of x_n -c is less than epsilon.
